heading: Joins in SQL – Mastering Data Relationships

blocks.text: JOINs allow combining rows from two or more tables based on related columns. They are essential for relational database queries.

list: INNER JOIN – returns only matching rows
LEFT JOIN – returns all rows from the left table, matching from right
RIGHT JOIN – returns all rows from the right table, matching from left
FULL OUTER JOIN – returns all rows from both tables

image.caption: Venn diagram showing different types of SQL joins.

blocks.text: Example: INNER JOIN to combine users with their orders:

code.content:
SELECT Users.name, Orders.amount
FROM Users
INNER JOIN Orders ON Users.id = Orders.user_id
WHERE Orders.amount > 100;

list: Self-Join – a table joined with itself
Cross Join – Cartesian product of two tables
Using JOIN with aggregate functions to summarize data
Multiple JOINs – joining 3 or more tables in a single query

blocks.title: Performance Tip
blocks.text: Indexes on join columns dramatically improve performance. Without indexes, large JOINs can be very slow.
Mini Exercise: Write a query to find users who have not placed any orders. Think about which JOIN type to use.
